Oldest part of Pune, narrow lanes with traditional wadas, Kasba Ganpati (Pune's gram daivat), old homes with wooden facades, authentic Maharashtrian neighborhood feel.

Paithani sarees, Kolhapuri chappals, copper vessels, Pune's traditional jewelry, handicrafts at Juna Bazaar, old coins and antiques, traditional perfumes (attar) in old city.

Irani bakery since 1955 near East Street. Famous for Shrewsbury biscuits, mawa cakes, cheese puffs. No-frills place, cash only, often has queues. Pune institution.
Where to try Maharashtrian thali?

Volunteer group conducting free/nominal cost walks every Sunday covering different heritage areas. Knowledgeable guides, 2-3 hour walks, advance registration required online.
Where to buy books on Pune history?

What's the detailed story of how Bajirao I built Shaniwar Wada and what was his vision for it?

Bajirao I's decision to build Shaniwar Wada in 1730 was strategic brilliance combined with grand vision. After becoming Peshwa at just 20 in 1720, Bajirao expanded Maratha territory dramatically but lacked a power center symbolizing this growing empire. He chose Pune over Satara (the official capital) to establish Peshwa supremacy independently. The location beside Mutha river provided water, while elevated ground offered defensive advantage. Bajirao personally supervised the construction starting January 10, 1730 (Saturday, hence 'Shaniwar'). His vision went beyond just a residence - it would be the nerve center of an empire stretching across India. He designed it to impress visitors and intimidate enemies with its grandeur. The seven-story palace would be visible from afar, announcing Maratha power. The complex layout included administrative sections for running the empire, military planning rooms for his continuous campaigns, cultural spaces to patronize arts, and diplomatic halls to receive ambassadors. Despite initial cost of just Rs. 16,110, Bajirao envisioned continuous expansion. He incorporated defensive innovations like spike-studded gates and multiple escape routes. The Hazari Karanje fountain demonstrated technological advancement. Bajirao lived here only eight years before his death in 1740, but his vision created the Maratha Empire's most iconic structure, from where his successors ruled much of India.

Don't touch the idol unless permitted during special darshan. The temple's energy comes from continuous worship since 1893 and millions of devotees' faith. Participate in aarti if possible - standing with joined hands, you can chant along or observe silently. The prasad (modak) is considered blessed food - accept with right hand and consume it respectfully. Photography inside is usually prohibited; respect this rule. Many non-Hindus visit and are welcomed - the temple represents Pune's inclusive culture. Learn basic terms: 'darshan' means viewing the deity, 'aarti' is the prayer ceremony, 'prasad' is blessed offering. The temple's social work reflects Hindu philosophy of service. Your respectful behavior honors both the religious site and cultural traditions.

I want to know about Kasturba Gandhi and Mahadev Desai's death at Aga Khan Palace. What were the circumstances?

The deaths of Kasturba Gandhi and Mahadev Desai at Aga Khan Palace represent the freedom struggle's profound personal sacrifices. Mahadev Desai, Gandhi's devoted secretary for 25 years, died suddenly on August 15, 1942, just six days after imprisonment. The stress of arrest, separation from family, and worry about the movement's future caused a massive heart attack. Gandhi was devastated, losing his 'right hand' who managed everything from correspondence to Gandhi's daily needs. Desai was cremated in the palace grounds where his samadhi stands today. Kasturba's death was prolonged suffering. Already in poor health, imprisonment worsened her chronic bronchitis. Despite British providing medical care, she declined steadily. Gandhi opposed British doctors' suggestion of penicillin injections, preferring nature cure, a decision that haunted him. Her final weeks saw her bedridden, struggling to breathe. On February 22, 1944, she died in Gandhi's arms after saying 'I am going now. No one should cry after I die.' Gandhi, who'd shared 62 years with her, was inconsolable. British allowed her cremation within palace grounds. These deaths transformed Aga Khan Palace from a prison to sacred ground. Gandhi later said losing them here was his greatest sacrifice for freedom. The palace preserves their rooms as shrines to their sacrifice.

Tell me about the architectural beauty and design of Aga Khan Palace.

Aga Khan Palace is an architectural masterpiece blending Italian and Islamic styles, built in 1892 by Sultan Muhammed Shah Aga Khan III. The palace took 5 years and Rs. 12 lakhs to build, employing 1000 workers including Italian architects. The central building covers 19,000 square feet with perfect symmetry. The most striking features are Italian arches creating beautiful corridors with play of light and shadow throughout the day. The palace has 5 halls and 11 rooms, each with 15-foot high ceilings providing natural cooling. Spacious verandahs on all sides allowed prisoners to walk while confined. The central courtyard design ensures cross-ventilation. Intricate wooden work on doors and windows shows local craftsmanship merged with European design. The palace uses local Deccan trap basalt giving it the distinctive dark color. The 19-acre garden was designed in Mughal char-bagh style with geometric patterns, water channels (now dry), and fruit orchards. Mango, tamarind, and neem trees, some over 100 years old, provide shade. The boundary wall runs 680 meters with guard towers at corners. The architecture emphasizes simplicity and elegance rather than ornamentation, perhaps prophetically suitable for housing Gandhi who epitomized simplicity. The building's orientation maximizes natural light while minimizing heat. Even today, the palace remains naturally cool in summer, testament to its brilliant design.

The museum displays international tributes to Gandhi, including letters from world leaders. A section covers the Quit India Movement's impact across India. Interactive displays explain Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence. The museum shop sells books, khadi products, and memorabilia. Every exhibit connects to the larger story of India's independence, making history tangible and emotional rather than just factual.
How did Gandhi spend his days during imprisonment at Aga Khan Palace?

Gandhi's 21 months at Aga Khan Palace (August 1942 to May 1944) followed a disciplined routine despite imprisonment. He woke at 4 AM for prayer and meditation, then walked in the palace corridors and garden for exercise - guards counted him walking up to 5 miles daily inside the compound. Morning was spent spinning khadi on his charkha, which he considered meditation and symbolic resistance. He read extensively from the palace library including religious texts - Gita, Bible, Quran - and wrote numerous letters, though British censored his correspondence. Afternoons involved tending a small vegetable garden he created, growing tomatoes, spinach, and papaya, insisting on physical labor's importance. He conducted prayer meetings with fellow prisoners every evening, singing bhajans and reading from various religious texts. He wrote articles and refined his philosophy, though publication was banned. He taught Kasturba to read and write Gujarati better. The tragic period included nursing Kasturba through her illness and mourning Mahadev Desai's death. He undertook a 21-day fast in February 1943, nearly dying, to protest British accusations about the Quit India violence. Despite personal tragedies, he maintained his principles - simple living, prayer, physical work, and intellectual pursuits. British provided newspapers which he read thoroughly, staying informed about war and independence developments. This routine sustained his spirit through the most personally difficult period of his life.
